Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 07:28PM - edited May 25, 2012 07:30PM by bikergal I, too, have had (knock wood) great results with Herceptin.  I was diagnosed in March 2007 with Stage IV breast cancer (widespread metastatic disease, including the liver), and after 6 cycles of TCH (H is Herceptin), my scans showed no evidence of disease.  Other than a new primary cancer in my "good" breast, I have stayed that to date.  I continued on Herceptin and Femara after stopping the chemo.  I hope your Mom has similarly great results.  You can read about other Herceptin success stories at Hersupport.org.  Indeed, one of the first women ever to receive Herceptin is NED (no evidence of disease) more than 18 years out, and she doesn't take any meds at all.  (She is profiled on this site.)    By the way, I have heard famous oncologists who specialize in breast cancer saying that they think they be able to cure Her2 positive breast cancer within 10 years.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2016 06:15PM bikergal wrote: I would get a second opinion if I were you. Now that your EF is normal, I would think it is time to consider resuming Herceptin. I have been on Herceptin for 9 years (along with other drugs)!
Posts.Title: Stopping Herceptin MuggleBorn Cafelovr

Posts.Content: May 24, 2013 05:46PM bikergal wrote: I would double check on the STD and LTD.  In my case, the LTD was much, much more that SSDI.  So, it is worth investigating whether your wife really waived coverage.  She also might be eligble for short term disability from the state, which actually can last for quite some time.  Another thoughts.  Summer is almost here. Can your wife hang on until summer vacation, or go out on short term leave, so as to get paid during the summer months? Good luck! BG
Posts.Title: Update on Wife - TDM-1 (Kadcyla), Insurance issues ERWMfromCentFla ERWMfromCentFla

Posts.Content: May 3, 2012 04:58PM bikergal wrote: Just to follow up on my previous post. . . . Many women in my support group see Dr. Smith, and they all love him.  He is from all accounts very compassionate and caring.  However, I personally have not been impressed by some of his treatment recommendations (for others), which did not seem consistent with evidence-based medicine.  Second opinions also have disagreed with his recommendations.  If you have other choices with respect to doctors that will administer intreathecal Herceptin, I would choose someone else, if you can get into see that person in a timely maner.  You should know that Dr. Slamon, who was the force behind Herceptin is at UCLA.  Although it is almost impossible to see him, his protegee, Dr. Hurvitz (spelling?) is more available.  The medical oncologists at UCSF, where I am treated, are excellent.  Getting in to see them, however, may be difficult.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 12:44AM bikergal wrote: No, luckily (knock wood) I do not need it at this time.  Just IV Herceptin for me.  Good luck!  You might also try posting on the Her2 support board -- www.her2support.org   People have posted there about intrathecal Herceptin.  If you indicate where you are located geographically, that might be helpful, too.    If you need further info about UCSF or Dr. Smith, I am happy to try and help.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 11:07PM bikergal wrote: I know one of my breast cancer friends' oncologist gave her intrathecal Herceptin for suspected leptominingeal metastases.  It was not in a trial.  The doctor was Dr. Garrett Smith in San Francisco.  I hope this helps.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 06:18PM bikergal wrote: You also might try Dr. Nancy Lin at Dana Farber in Boston.  She has done a lot of research on brain metastases, and also specializes in Her2 positive disease.  (I also have heard that she is very nice.)  I have no idea, however if she would give intrathecal Herceptin.  Her research abstract and link to her profile are below.  Research Abstract Dr. Lin is a medical oncologist at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute focusing on the care of women with breast cancer. Her research focuses upon developing novel therapies for women with brain metastases, and upon exploring mechanisms of resistance and response to HER2-based therapy. Publications View All Publications   http://www.dfhcc.harvard.edu/membership/profile/member/599/0/

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 01:34PM bikergal wrote: What about going to UCSF for a third opinion?  My oncologist there, Dr. Hope Rugo, is tops in the breast cancer field.  She is not afraid to recommend an aggressive approach.  On the other hand, she is like a computer and very knowledgeable about every study, tumor biology, etc,, and wouldn't recommend a course of action that doesn't have a reasonable chance of success.  (Her bedside manner could be better, but I am sure she would be fine for a third opinion.)  Good luck with your decision!  It is so hard to make these types of decisions.
Posts.Title: Treatment Dilemna exbrnxgrl exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 09:28PM bikergal wrote: Kristin, I think you should make your feelings known.  I believe I am a patient of the same famous UCSF oncologist.  I schedule an appointment with her (not her nurse) for a couple of days after each scan.  I now have scans every four months.  That way if anything shows up on the scan, I know I can talk with her about what to do, if I am willing to wait long enough for her to come into the exam room.  (I see the NP first.)  I have been NED for the last 3.5 years, other than a recurrence in the contralateral breast, so, at least in her view, I haven't had much of a need to speak with her.  If in her view, I don't need to see her, she either is very short with me or encourages me to e-mail her instead of seeing her.  I schedule appointments with her nurse for in between scans. It can be extremely frustrating.  I think UCSF needs to be made aware of what is going on.  That said, I think you are in very good hands.  She is extremely smart and knowledgeable.
Posts.Title: survey: how often do you see your oncologist? kristinpianista Lena

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2013 12:06AM bikergal wrote: What a nightmare!  It is terrible that you have to deal with this on top of the medical issues.  Do you get your insurance through your job or your husband's job?  If so, maybe someone in your HR department can help.  When I had an issue with insurance coverage, I was surprised that our HR group was willing to intervene, and got the issue resolved quickly.  (It was a denial of coverage of an aspect of an operation that I had, and was pre-approved for.)  The insurer wants to keep big companies happy.  Sorry not to have any better ideas.  Can you appeal again?
Posts.Title: ?? Ins denies brain radiation. What to do? formygirls Cafelovr

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2010 01:33AM bikergal wrote: Go for it!  I exercised all through chemo, and I think it helped me do better than I otherwise would have.  Although I had bone mets (in addition to mets in my liver and lymph nodes), my doctor didn't impose any restrictions (she even said skiing moguls was OK), and I wasn't in any real pain.  So I kept on biking and added some running to the mix.  After a few months of chemo, it was a bit harder, but I didn't stop.  I think I have exercised more since diagnosis than before, since I decided to work less, and I made exercise a priority.  Really, if you can do it, it will help keep you mentally sane in addition to the physical benefits.  Set some achievable goals, and then try to meet them.  I found that this was something within my control at a time that nothing else seemed to be. Now I am just on Herceptin, so there is no excuse not to exercise.  I hope to hike up a 14,000 foot peak in a couple of weeks.  (Although I have not had much time to recover from my mastectomy.)    As for the gym, I am terrible about going, since I don't enjoy working out at a gym.  But it sounds like you enjoy it.   And this isn't trivial.  I know that once my nurse practitioner asked me if I had been riding or running recently, and I said "no."  She looked very concerned, until I explained that it had rained the last few weekends in a row.  But she knows that exercise is important to me, and really encourages it.   I have been very fortunate to be NED for the last three years.  But I think it is important to try to limit what cancer takes from you.  And if going to the gym is something you enjoy, you should make up your mind that you will keep going, even if it ends up that you have to reduce your workout somewhat.
Posts.Title: Anyone Stage IV still going to the gym? Lynn1 KSkier
